Package me.wobblyyyy.edt.arrays

Class DynamicFloat

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.edt.DynamicArray<java.lang.Float>
      • me.wobblyyyy.edt.arrays.DynamicFloat
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Arrayable<java.lang.Float>
    public class DynamicFloat
extends DynamicArray<java.lang.Float>
    A specialized dynamic array type designed to reduce clutter in code (and the amount of those damn diamond brackets).

    This class doesn't actually provide any utility other than making it easier to construct and access a specific type of dynamic array.

    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description

      Create a new DynamicArray instance without any values or elements.

      DynamicFloat​(java.lang.Float... elements)
      Create a new DynamicArray instance using a plain array of elements as the initialization elements.
      DynamicFloat​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Float> elements)
      Create a new DynamicArray instance by using an ArrayList instance to provide initialization values for the newly-constructed array.
      DynamicFloat​(Arrayable<java.lang.Float> arrayable)
      Create a new DynamicArray instance by using an Arrayable object as the "base" that the dynamic array should be based on.

    • Constructor Detail

      • DynamicFloat

        public DynamicFloat()
        Create a new DynamicArray instance without any values or elements. Because there are no values or elements inserted into the array at construction, the array will be entirely empty. New values and elements can be added to the DynamicArray using any of the insertion or append methods provided in this class.
        See Also:
        DynamicArray.add(Object), DynamicArray.add(Object[]), DynamicArray.add(int, Object)

      • DynamicFloat

        public DynamicFloat​(java.lang.Float... elements)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance using a plain array of elements as the initialization elements. These elements can be updated later with the methods provided in the DynamicArray class.
        Parameters:
        elements - an array, containing all of the Object instances that should be set as the DynamicArray's contents upon construction.

      • DynamicFloat

        public DynamicFloat​(int minSize)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance without any data. Instead of data, we have a lovely integer, representing the minimum allocation size of the array. This allocation size can be used to boost performance. Allocating a larger size uses more memory but reduces CPU time when dealing with arrays of that size of slightly smaller.
        Parameters:
        minSize - the minimum size of the array. By default, this value is 10. Larger arrays can have sizes up to 10,000, 100,000, or even 1,000,000 - it's entirely up to you.

      • DynamicFloat

        public DynamicFloat​(int minSize,
                    java.lang.Object[] elements)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance using a plain array of elements as the initialization elements. These elements can be updated later with the methods provided in the DynamicArray class.
        Parameters:
        minSize - the array's minimum size.
        elements - an array, containing all of the Object instances that should be set as the DynamicArray's

      • DynamicFloat

        public DynamicFloat​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Float> elements)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance by using an ArrayList instance to provide initialization values for the newly-constructed array.
        Parameters:
        elements - an ArrayList of elements that should be set to the dynamic array's contents. These elements must be of the same type the newly-created DynamicArray is of.

      • DynamicFloat

        public DynamicFloat​(Arrayable<java.lang.Float> arrayable)
        Create a new DynamicArray instance by using an Arrayable object as the "base" that the dynamic array should be based on. This can be useful when converting a static array to a dynamic array.
        Parameters:
        arrayable - the array object that should be the base of the new dynamic array.
